newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak FinMin says sees H1 real GDP between 5-6pct.
newsitem.headline: Slovak FinMin says sees H1 real GDP between 5-6pct.

text.p: Slovak Finance Minister Sergej Kozlik said on Tuesday real gross domestic product (GDP) growth for the first half was in the "upper half" between five to six percent.
Kozlik said he considered the government target for 1997 GDP growth of at least six percent as "achievable."
"There have been some positive signals in the economy in recent days so, I think the target is achievable," Kozlik told Reuters during a regular government meeting.
"In the first half of the year GDP growth will be in the upper half of between five to six percent," he added.
Kozlik said industrial and construction output were still showing an uptrend which supported expectations of "further economic growth".
Slovakia's GDP rose by a real 5.1 percent in the first quarter of this year, after real, full year 1996 growth of 7.3 percent.
The country's real industrial output rose by 7.7 percent, year-on-year, in June, while construction output showed an annual increase of 2.1 percent.
"Furthermore, there are still some projects that have to be started which can help the economy to grow further, such as EXIM Bank or the revitalisation law," Kozlik said.

Slovakia, battling long-lasting problems stemming from a growing trade deficit, approved a state-run Export- Import bank earlier this year in an attempt to boost sagging exports. The bank has yet to start its operations.
The trade gap widened to 32.572 billion crowns in the first seven months of the year, from 29.859 billion in the January-May period.

The revitalisation law, which still has to be approved by the parliament, is planned to help overcome financial problems of both state-run and private companies by easing their debt burdens to state and to some commercial banks.
